page.title: 01THE CAMBRIDGESHIRE UPLANDS
page.content: The area consists of undulating, rather featureless, arable farmland. Large fields, with deep drainage ditches, provide for the efficient use of heavy agricultural machinery. Small farmsteads and barns have been replaced by large factory-built sheds. There are a few hedgerows and deciduous woodlands, the latter preserved as game cover and for fox hunting. Recently established studs and paddocks have increased grazing land, and saplings are being planted on road side verges. Trees abound in the villages. With new housing estates, village populations are expanding, but few inhabitants are employed locally. The majority travel to work by car in neighbouring towns or to London. Bus services are infrequent.
